DOC.HEAD: SEC Proposes Stiffer Disclosure Rules for Mutual Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking public comment on proposed new rules that would require mutual funds to simplify and expand the information they are required to supply investors. The SEC agreed to submit the proposals to public scrutiny on Thursday. One proposals seeks to clarify descriptions of funds to investors, a second would provide better measures of fund performance and a third would require disclosure of who is making fund investment decisions. At least one of the proposals, requiring funds to identify those managing their stock portfolios, is expected to meet with the stiffest industry opposition, SEC staffers acknowledged. ``I would say the majority of the industry people that we've heard from think it's a bad idea,'' said Kathryn McGrath of the SEC. Ms. McGrath, head of the SEC's Division of Investment Management, conceded that previous attempts to implement a fund manager disclosure rule were ``blown out of the water by a wave of criticism.'' The Investment Company Institute, a mutal fund industry group, opposes portfolio manager disclosure, claiming it would be an additional burden for the funds and create a ``superstar'' system of fund managers. ``We did not agree with the fund manager disclosure, which places undue emphasis on the cult of personality. It ignores the actual basis on which funds hire advisers,'' said Betty K. Hart, a spokeswoman for the trade group. ``In 1972, 1982 and 1984 this issue has come up and we have always opposed it. We still oppose it. There are some very succesful funds that run by committee,'' she added. Ms. Hart said the ICI was willing to go along with the disclosure rule in just two instances: ``where a fund promotes an individual to the press and the investment public, or if the individual is of such critical importance to the advisory organization that it would cease to exist in the same manner if they left.'' The two other proposals are less controversial. To simply information in a mutual fund's prospectus, the SEC staff suggested shortening tables listing a fund's total return per share. To provide investors with more information to easily evaluate a fund, the staff proposed following one of two alternatives: A fund's managers would be required either to discuss and analyze its fiscal year performance in relation to its investment objectives or compare its total returns over one-, five- and 10-year periods to the performance of a securities index. The commission, which regulates investment companies as well as the securities industry, voted to submit the proposed rules for a 60-day public comment period. Following that period, Ms. McGrath said her staff will review comments _ both pro and con _ make any changes deemed necessary and submit the proposed rule changes to the commissioners ``and they will vote it up or down.'' She said the staff hoped to submit the proposals to the commission by late spring or early summer.
